Char: Methods:
Study type: Cluster RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Setting: USA, Dental practice

Study dates: Not reported

Recruitment method: Letters to dental practices and presentations at local dental societies.
Char: Participants:
Participants: Dental hygiene patients (N = 633, Avg. age = 36.2, 100% Male)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chewing tobacco and Snuff

Proportion using combustible tobacco: 0.7%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: Usual dental hygiene visit. 

Provider: Dental hygienist.

Duration and intensity of support: 1 face-to-face session, average 60 minutes.

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: Counselling for dental patients to quit using tobacco, using a 7 component protocol.

Provider: Dentists and dental hygienists.

Duration and intensity of support: 1 face-to-face session, average 60 minutes; phone-based contact within 2 weeks of visit to ask if they had read the materials, looked at the video, and either quit or is now willing to set a quit date.

Pharmacotherapy: None
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: Sustained

Longest follow-up: 12 months

Biochemical validation: Not done
Char: Study funding source: Preparation of the manuscript was supported in part by Grant #1 RO1 HL48768 from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute.

Char: Methods:
Study type: RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Duration and intensity of support: N/A

Char: Interventions:

Char: Methods:
Study type: Factorial RCT (2x2)

Study registration: NCT00820495

Setting: USA, Community (Web-based)

Study dates: 2008-2011

Recruitment method: Online marketing campaign and marketing website.
Char: Participants:
Participants: 25 years and older, community residents (N = 1683, Avg. age = 37.9 years, 2.5% Female)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chewing tobacco, Snuff, Snus

Proportion using combustible tobacco: 8.0%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: 0%
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: Self-help material, sent through post.

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: N/A

Pharmacotherapy: None.

 

Intervention 2: Self-help material, sent through post + Fully-automated, tailored, interactive enhanced web-based smokeless tobacco cessation intervention used in the ChewFree trial.

Provider: Web-based

Duration and intensity of support: N/A 

Pharmacotherapy: None.

 

Intervention 3: Self-help material, sent through post + Proactive calls from the California Tobacco Chewers’ Helpline.

Provider: Trained counsellors.

Duration and intensity of support: Up to 4 follow-up calls to review the personalized plan, discuss relapse prevention, and encourage another quit attempt if needed.

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 4: Self-help material, sent through post + Fully-automated, tailored, interactive enhanced web-based smokeless tobacco cessation intervention used in the ChewFree trial + Proactive calls from the California Tobacco Chewers’ Helpline.

Provider: Web-based and trained counsellors.

Duration and intensity of support: Up to 4 follow-up calls to review the personalized plan, discuss relapse prevention, and encourage another quit attempt if needed.

Pharmacotherapy: None
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 7 day point prevalence

Longest follow-up: 6 months

Biochemical validation: Not done
Char: Study funding source: National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health (R01-CA084225).

Char: Methods:
Study type: RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Setting: USA, Community (Web-based)

Study dates: 2013

Recruitment method: Nationwide online marketing.
Char: Participants:
Participants: Adults, community residents (N = 407, Avg. age = 35.2 years, 2.5% Female)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chewing tobacco, Snuff, Snus

Proportion using combustible tobacco: 7.1%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: 0%
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: MyLastDip, interactive web-based intervention.

Provider: Web-based.

Duration and intensity of support: Program content grouped according to three sequential frames: preparing to quit, quitting, and staying quit. If a participant reported a lapse, then the program would provide tailored content on lessons learned and starting over (“retooling”).

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: MyLastDip, interactive web-based intervention with NRT.

Provider: Web-based.

Duration and intensity of support: N/A 

Pharmacotherapy: 2 boxes of Nicorette® Lozenges (4mg; 108 lozenges/box) mailed; NRT for 12 weeks, could ask for up to 3 months.
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 7 day point prevalence 

Longest follow-up: 6 months

Biochemical validation: Not done
Char: Author declarations of interest: Dr. Ebbert has received consulting fees from GlaxoSmithKline and has received research support from Pfizer, Orexigen and JHP outside of the current study. GlaxoSmithKline provided the nicotine lozenges for the study but had no role in the conduct of the study (data collection, management, analysis, and interpretation), in the preparation, review, approval of the manuscript, or in the decision to submit the manuscript for publication.
Char: Study funding source: National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health (R01-CA142952).

Char: Methods:
Study type: RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Intervention 3: Nicotine patches with electronic diary to record data.

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: N/A 

Pharmacotherapy: Nicotine patches (42 mg/day), 8 weeks with taper. Subjects wore 3 patches in weeks 0–4, two in weeks 5-6, one in weeks 7-8.

 

Intervention 4: Nicotine patches with electronic diary to record data.

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: N/A 

Pharmacotherapy: Nicotine patches (63 mg/day), 8 weeks with taper. Subjects wore 3 patches in weeks 0–4, two in weeks 5-6, one in weeks 7-8.
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 7 day point prevalence and sustained

Biochemical validation: Urine anabasine <2 ng/ml

Char: Methods:
Study type: Cluster RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Setting: USA, College

Study dates: 1999-2000

Recruitment method: Contacting certified athletic trainers (ATCs) at colleges.
Char: Participants:
Participants: Collegiate baseball athletes (N = 637, Avg. age = Not reported; 100% Male)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chewing tobacco, Snuff, Spit

Proportion using combustible tobacco: 66.0%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: Usual anti-tobacco education offered at their colleges.

Provider: Not reported

Duration and intensity of support: Not reported

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: Oral cancer screening with feedback and brief
counselling, athletic trainer follow-up support, and a peer-led educational baseball team meeting.

Provider: Dentist or dental hygienist for oral screening and counselling, certified athletic trainer for follow-up support, and peer leader for the education session.

Duration and intensity of support: 1 oral screening and counselling session (10-15 min); trainer follow-up on scheduled quit date and in 3 group booster
sessions scheduled 1 week apart - trainers referred athletes wishing more intensive support to tobacco cessation counselors; 1 interactive educational meeting (50-60 min); all face-to-face sessions.

Pharmacotherapy: None
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 30 day point prevalence

Longest follow-up: 12 months

Biochemical validation: Not done
Char: Study funding source: Tobacco Surtax Fund of the State of California (Grant 4RT-0068) through the Tobacco-Related Disease Research Program of the University of California.

Intervention 4: Group behavioural therapy with nicotine gum (2mg).

Provider: Trained therapist

Pharmacotherapy: NRT patch and mint snuff (3 tins per week) for 10 weeks.

Study type: RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Setting: USA, Community (Rural)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chews/dips

Proportion using combustible tobacco: Not reported

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: Text-message support. 

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: 4 weeks; participants received two messages a day during weeks 1 and 4, and up to three a day during weeks 2 and 3.

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: Text-messages supporting gradual reduction of tobacco. Week 1: participants chew as usual and text “s” every time; Over the next three weeks, reduced by 1/3 each week down to zero use. Those with a baseline mean of 10 or more uses per day offered an extra reduction week. The last day of program was considered the quit date.

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: 4 weeks; participants received two messages a day during weeks 1 and 4, and up to three a day during weeks 2 and 3.

Pharmacotherapy: None
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 7 day point prevalence

Longest follow-up: 6 months

Biochemical validation: NicAlert semi-quantitative strips < 10 ng/mL

Char: Participants:

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:

Provider: Not reported

Duration and intensity of support: 1 face-to-face session (lasted on average 1 min).

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: Yogic breathing exercise and very brief quit advice. Two breathing exercises, ‘Kapalbhati’ (normal deep inhalation-forceful exhalation) and ‘Anulom vilom’ (alternate nostril breathing), were chosen.

Study type: RCT

Setting: USA, Community

Char: Participants:

Smokeless tobacco product: Not reported

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: Tobacco cessation counselling intended to reinforce and personalize the procedures described in the self-help materials.

Provider: Researchers experienced in motivational interviewing.

Duration and intensity of support: 3 proactive phone-based counselling sessions - Call #1 was 1 week after randomization, Call #2 was 2–3 days after participant’s quit date, Call #3 was 14–21 days following call #2.

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: NRT

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: N/A

Pharmacotherapy: 3 boxes of Nicorette® Mini-Lozenges (4 mg): 81 lozenges/box. Tapered usage over time: weeks 1–6 = 1 lozenge every 1 to 2 hour, weeks 7–9 = 1 lozenge every 2–4 hour, and weeks 10–12 = 1 lozenge every 4–8hr. Additional boxes could be requested. 

 

Intervention 3: Tobacco cessation counselling intended to reinforce and personalize the procedures described in the self-help materials + NRT.

Provider: Researchers experienced in motivational interviewing.

Duration and intensity of support: 3 proactive phone-based counselling sessions - Call #1 was 1 week after randomization, Call #2 was 2–3 days after participant’s quit date, Call #3 was 14–21 days following call #2.

Pharmacotherapy: 3 boxes of Nicorette® Mini-Lozenges (4 mg): 81 lozenges/box. Tapered usage over time: weeks 1–6 = 1 lozenge every 1 to 2 hour, weeks 7–9 = 1 lozenge every 2–4hr, and weeks 10–12 = 1 lozenge every 4–8hr. Additional boxes could be requested.

Char: Participants:
Participants: Adults seeking dental care (N = 467, Avg. age = 45.6 years, 36.6% Female)

Smokeless tobacco product: Snus

Proportion using combustible tobacco: 8.9%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: Assistance for tobacco cessation (face-to-face information on the consequences of tobacco on oral health).

Provider: Dentist or dental hygienist.

Duration and intensity of support: Not reported

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: A structured very brief advice based on the 5 A's.

Provider: Dentist or dental hygienist.

Duration and intensity of support: One face-to-face session of 5 minutes duration.

Pharmacotherapy: None
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 7 day point prevalence and sustained

Longest follow-up: 6 months

Biochemical validation: Not done
Char: Author declarations of interest: The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest. No financial disclosures were reported by the authors of this paper.
Char: Study funding source: National Board of Health and Welfare (Contract Grant Number 2.4-43860/2011).

Char: Methods:
Study type: Cluster RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Setting: USA, College

Study dates: 1990-1993

Recruitment method: Colleges with football and baseball teams enrolled through athletic directors/coaches; athletes recruited through team meetings.
Char: Participants:
Participants: Athletes from football and baseball teams (N = 360, Avg. age = Not reported, 100% Male)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chew/dip

Proportion using combustible tobacco: < 2.0%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: No treatment.

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: N/A

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: Athletic team-based cessation program, consisting of oral examination, counselling and advice to quit, with nicotine gum. 

Provider: Dentist, dental hygienist, non-ST-using peers.

Duration and intensity of support: 15-20 min one-time face-to-face interaction with 5-10 min phone-based contact on the quit date and 1 month. 

Pharmacotherapy: Nicotine gum (2mg) was also offered to mitigate withdrawal symtpoms.
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 30 day point prevalence

Longest follow-up: 12 months

Biochemical validation: Salivary cotinine (cutoffs not provided)
Char: Study funding source: Tobacco Surtax Fund of the State of California through the Tobacco-Related Disease Research Program of the University of California.

Char: Methods:
Study type: Cluster RCT

Study registration: Not reported

Setting: USA, High school (Rural)

Study dates: 2000-2005

Recruitment method: Eligible schools enrolled by contacting the principal; individual subjects recruited via cover letter and consent form included in the student registration packs.
Char: Participants:
Participants: 17 years or younger, high school students (N = 4731, Avg. age = Not reported, 100% Male)

Smokeless tobacco product: Chew/dip

Proportion using combustible tobacco: 6.0%

Proportion using products containing areca or betel: Not reported
Char: Interventions:
Intervention 1: No treatment.

Provider: N/A

Duration and intensity of support: N/A

Pharmacotherapy: None

 

Intervention 2: A peer-led educational session, an oral examination with feedback, and three nurse-led group cessation counselling sessions.

Provider: School nurse and student peers.

Duration and intensity of support: 3-4 weeks (3 once a week 1-hour face-to-face sessions following 45 min peer session and oral exam).

Pharmacotherapy: None
Char: Outcomes:
Definition of abstinence: 30 day point prevalence 

Longest follow-up: 12 months

Biochemical validation: Not done
Char: Study funding source: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research, National Institutes of Health (Grant Number US DHHS NIH/NIDCR P60DE13058).
